messages.message:
@Parvez, it looks like the cluster isn’t part of the accounts you shared.

I used this command to check `aws eks list-clusters --region us-east-2 | grep 'inmodev-use2-sandbox-infra-services-eks-cluster'`
You might have to use --profile just check how are you using the credentials shared with you

I used by exporting `AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID` and `AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY` environment variables.

It appears the credentials belong to `instabase-sandbox` (ID: *****), but I need access to `instabase-monitoring-dev` account (ID: *****)

`$ aws sts get-caller-identity`
```{
  "UserId": "***",
  "Account": "***",
  "Arn": "arn:aws:iam::***:user/terraform-user"
}```

Can you try using this credential https://start.1password.com/open/i?a=VAAEGM2JPRH27E45XRQMXG5UKA&v=qbm6ysedz5bm7bzfvh3e[…]i=hpgovwo2ht4dkzazewkd62axva&h=team-instabase.1password.com (https://start.1password.com/open/i?a=VAAEGM2JPRH27E45XRQMXG5UKA&v=qbm6ysedz5bm7bzfvh3ezf33be&i=hpgovwo2ht4dkzazewkd62axva&h=team-instabase.1password.com)

It worked this time. I was initially confused, I thought `***` was the access key ID associated with this account. But after restarting 1Password, I noticed the correct key (`***`) is now being used.

It might have been an error on my end, but all good now, I'm able to list the `inmodev-use2-sandbox-infra-services-eks-cluster` cluster with the credentials. :simple_smile:

I was able to upgrade the `vpc-cni` add-on to the default version (`v1.19.0-eksbuild.1`) for EKS 1.30.
Thanks @Parvez :pray:
@abhishekk can you redact and rotate whatever access keys you shared in your message? Shouldn’t post those in slack (even if it’s just the access key and not the secret part)

@astpierre, are Access Key IDs considered secret? Since this is an internal engineering channel, I was under the impression that only the Secret Access Key is treated as secret.

That said, I've redacted the Access Key, Account IDs, User ARNs etc from the message to be safe.
